config.question: How did abolitionist rhetoric condemning most slaveholders as sadistic tyrants influence southern rhetoric in support of slavery?

choices.content: Paternalistic rhetoric found competition in the writings of southern abolitionists.
The rhetoric of those defending slavery found new arguments among German scientists.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Those writing in support of slavery increased their claims that blacks needed their paternal care. Although some historians have argued that paternalism was part of a social system organized more like a family hierarchy than a brutal, profit-making arrangement, there was no inconsistency between planters’ paternalism and capitalism. Slaves were a form of capital—both the main tools of production for a booming economy and an asset valuable for their rising prices. See L.O. 11.2 What divided and united white southern society?
